Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Situation2: They are approached by someone struggling with personal or family issues and need to provide consistent guidance and encouragement.
Story: I was just leaving the church office when I ran into Mark, an old acquaintance from college. He greeted me with a warm smile and asked if I knew any good restaurants nearby—he wanted to take his wife out for their anniversary. I could see he was hoping for a thoughtful suggestion, maybe even a story or two about my own experiences. As I started to answer, Mrs. Thompson, a member of my congregation, hurried over. Her eyes were red, and her voice trembled as she asked if I had a moment to talk. She needed guidance—her son was in trouble again, and she didn’t know what to do. I felt the weight of both their expectations pressing on me: Mark’s friendly request for help, and Mrs. Thompson’s desperate need for support. My mind raced, torn between the casual camaraderie of an old friend and the deep responsibility I felt as a pastor. I could feel my heart pounding, caught in the tension of wanting to be present for both, but knowing I couldn’t give either the attention they truly deserved at the same time.
